abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the Second Social
            Investment Fund (SIF) Project is rated as satisfactory,
            sustainability as highly likely, institutional development
            impact as substantial, bank performance as satisfactory, and
            borrower performance as satisfactory. The Social Investment
            Fund managed to implement social investments on a large
            scale, was able to reach the poor, in all cases improved
            physical infrastructure, and generated positive final
            outcomes with its investments in health and water. The
            lessons learned include: a) A lack of impact on school
            achievement can be resolved by working more closely with the
            Ministry of Education to design integrated interventions
            that include infrastructure and teaching processes. b) High
            administrative costs can be reduced by maintaining greater
            stability in the amount of resources allocated to the Fund.
            It is useful to explore mechanisms to provide greater
            flexibility in staffing so that the SIF can adjust to
            variation in demand. c) It is important to review the
            subproject cycle and eliminate unnecessary steps in order to
            avoid delays attributable to process within the Fondo Social
            de Emergencia project cycle that are excessively expensive.
            d) Delays due to the lack of counterpart resources from the
            municipalities can be avoided by allocating more resources
            to the municipalities. e) Sector ministries should be
            involved in working with the SIF to maintain consistency of
            sectoral policies.
